info.name: NetBeez API
info.description:
The NetBeez API allows dashboard administrators the ability to integrate NetBeez with other solutions such as tools, reporting & analytics solutions, and more. This documentation outlines available APIs that can be used along with available options and examples.

Contact support for any questions you may have.

# Authentication

In order to authenticate with the NetBeez API, you must create an API key. This can be done via the NetBeez Dashboard. NetBeez Administrators can perform the following steps to create an API key:

1. Navigation to Settings by clicking the cog icon located in the menu bar.
2. Click on "API Keys" located in the left settings menu.
3. Click "Generate API Key" button and fill out the form.
    

Once generated the API Key can be used by placing an "Authorization" header in any request to the API, see the below APIs for usage.

# Using Postman

We want to make exploring and utilizing our API easier for our customers. This is why we now provide our customers with a Postman project that can be downloaded onto your computer. This allows you to test out available APIs and can help you integrate NetBeez into your IT infrastructure.

Download the project by clicking the "Run in Postman" button at the top of the page. Our Postman project uses variables to set the FQDN and API Key to your NetBeez Dashboard across all API calls in the project. To make it easier to use Postman for your NetBeez installation you can set up an environment for NetBeez. To learn how to do this [watch this video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wArvaHYdw2I) from Postman. Add the following variables to your environment:

- `HOSTNAME`: Set this to the FQDN of your NetBeez Dashboard.
- `API_KEY`: Set this to a generated API Key. See the above Authentication section for more information.
    

# Future API Changes (Version 13.0+)

We are implementing changes, starting in version 13.0, which will affect future versions of the API. These changes will go into effect for all new API changes we release and will be backward compatible with existing APIs for 2 versions after deprecation notices have been announced.

1. `POST` and `PUT` will be standardized into the same request format (JSONAPI) that we use for `GET` requests. This is to help streamline API consumption and also provide a very important update to how we manage relationships of data resources.
    
    1. With these changes, the API will allow for [upserting and removal of relationships](#folder-670b7e0c-98e4-44b6-9875-96233d01330b), which means consumers of the API will no longer have to provide all relationship information when updating dependent data resources. See the reference section for more details.
        
2. Some endpoints include supplemental relationship data by default and that will no longer be the case going forward. This is to help reduce payload sizes in situations where included relationship data isn't needed by consumers of the API.
    1. Consumers of the API can still retrieve the relationship data, however, it will need to be specifically requested from the available options of an API call. For example, [GET /agents](#request-4425180-f0ffc514-ddbd-45ef-ac52-fe08a86de944) currently automatically includes `network_interface` information, and once updated with this change the API calls will need to specifically request `network_interface` information using `include=network_interface` query parameter.

# Latest Version: 14.1

See the [changelog](#folder-4425180-057dfa24-071c-4d68-aaf5-df01e3cb302c) for changes for the latest version of NetBeez.

query.description:
The `stubbed` parameter provides a slimmed down version of `agent` attributes, see list of attributes above. `stubbed` will be one of the following values:

- `true`
- `false`
Filter `agents` based on `name`. This filter is a string search, any string matches for `name` will be provided.
Filter `agents` by `name` based on a provided regex pattern. This filter will return any `agents` that match `name` to the provided regex.

Filter `agents` based on `category`. `category` can be one of the following values:
- `network_agent`
- `remote_worker_agent`

Filter `agents` based on `agent_classes`.  `agent_classes` include following categories: 
- `container`
- `faste`
- `wireless`
-  `cumulus`
-  `external`
-  `gige`
-  `software`
-  `virtual`
-  `mac`
- `windows`
- `igel`

You can filter on a single `agent_class` or multiple `agent_classes` by providing the `agent classes` as a comma separated list.
Filter `agents` based on `active` status. `active` will filter` agents` by if the `agent` is reachable or not.

Filter `agents` based on `active_ts`.  This filter allows you to provide a single operator and value(s) to filter `active_ts` and `agents` that fall within the parameters.
For the `<=>`(between) operator use the `filter[active_ts][value1]` and `filter[active_ts][value2]` providing an epoch timestamp for each.
For the `<=,<,>,>=` operators use the `filter[active_ts][value]` providing an epoch timestamp.
Use if `filter[active_ts][operator]` is provided and is one of the following: `<=,<,>,>=`.  An epoch timestamp should be entered.
Use if `filter[active_ts][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.  An epoch timestamp should be entered.
Use if `filter[active_ts][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.  An epoch timestamp should be entered.
Filter `agents` based on `agent_groups`.  You can filter on a single `agent_group` or multiple `agent_groups` by providing the `agent_groups` as a comma separated list of `ids`.
Filter `agents` based on `critical_alerts` minimum by providing a number. This filter can be used independently or in conjunction with `filter[critical_alerts][max]`.
Filter `agents` based on `critical_alerts` maximum by providing a number. This filter can be used independently or in conjunction with `filters[critical_alerts][min]`.
Filter `agents` based on `warning_alerts` minimum by providing a number. This filter can be used independently or in conjunction with `filter[warning_alerts][max]`.
Filter `agents` based on `warning_alerts` maximum by providing a number. This filter can be used independently or in conjunction with `filters[warning_alerts][min]`.

*Depreciated*: This filter has been renamed to filter[in_incident]. filter[in_incident] will no longer work in 16.0.x.

Filter `agents` based on whether or not they have an open incident at the time of the request.
Filter `agents` based on whether or not they have an open incident at the time of the request.
Use `page[offset]` to specify which page, as a number, of the results you would like to return in the payload.  By default the first page is returned.
Use `page[limit]` to specify how many results to return on each page.  The default limit is 25.

Order payload results based on provided attributes.  You may provide a single attribute or multiple attributes as a comma separated list.  The attributes will be applied in the order they are provided.  Use in conjunction with `order[direction]`.  You may only order attributes in the same direction.  Available attributes for ordering are:

- `id`
- `name`
- `agent_class`
- `software_version`
- `active` (status)
- `open_incident`
Use if `order[attributes]` is provided and provide either `asc` or `desc` direction.

request.description:
This endpoint gives the ability to delete a specific `agent`. This will removed `agent` from the NetBeez dashboard and queued to be permanently deleted. All agent associated data (eg. results, statistics, metrics, etc.) will also be permanently deleted.

**Note**: Please ensure the `agent` has been disconnected from the network before deleting the `agent`, otherwise the `agent` may re-register with the NetBeez server.

variable.description: Provide the `id` of the `agent` you wish to update.

request.description:
This endpoint gives the ability to update specific `agent` information for an `agent` registred with the NetBeez server.

See the [Agent ](#folder-85f1a1bf-d7fa-48df-a7e1-9704a1feb250) data structure reference for additional information.

**Note:** This endpoint does not support our new JSONAPI based create/update payloads but will in the near future. This endpoint will be backwards compatible with the current format for two versions once JSONAPI based payloads have been release for this endpoint.

query.description:
Filter `agent_log` based on `source`.  You can filter on a single `source` or multiple `sources` by providing the `sources` as a comma separated list.  Available `sources` are:

- `alerts`
- `wpa_supplicant`
- `dhcp`

Filter `agent_log` based on `severity`.  `severity` follows syslog `severity` categories:  

- 0: `emergency`
- 1: `alert`
- 2: `critical`
- 3: `error`
- 4: `warning`
- 5: `notice`
- 6: `info`
- 7: `debug`

You can filter on a single `severity` or multiple `severities` by providing the `severities` as a comma separated list.  Number (6,7) or string (info,debug) representations for `severity` can be provided.

Filter `agent_log` based on `network_interface`.  You can filter on a single `network_interface` or multiple `network_interfaces` as a comma separated list.  Available `network_interfaces` are:

- `eth0`
- `wlan0`

Filter `agent_log` based on `event_code`.   This filter is a string search, any string matches for `event_code` will be provided.  Examples:

- "CTRL-EVENT-DISCONNECT"
- "DISCONNECT"
- " CONN"

Filter `agent_log` based on `message`.   This filter is a string search, any string matches for `message` will be provided.  Examples:

- "dhcp"
- "SSID"
- "dhclient"

Filter `agent_log` based on `occurred_at`.  This filter allows you to provide a single operator and value(s) to filter `occurred_at` and `agent_logs` that fall within the parameters.  

For the `<=>`(between) operator use the `filter[occurred_at][value1]` and `filter[occurred_at][value2]` providing a unix timestamp for each.  

For the `<=,<,>,>=` operators use the `filter[occurred_at][value]` providing a unix timestamp.
Use if `filter[occurred_at][operator]` is provided and is one of the following: `<=,<,>,>=`
Use if `filter[occurred_at][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.
Use if `filter[occurred_at][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.

This parameter will allow for the inclusion of any `alerts` generated for the specified `agent`. By default `alerts` are not included. Available values are:

- `true`
- `false`

Order payload results based on provided attributes.  You may provide a single attribute or multiple attributes as a comma separated list.  The attributes will be applied in the order they are provided.  Use in conjunction with `order[direction]`.  You may only order attributes in the same direction.  Available attributes for ordering are:

- `id`
- `severity`
- `message`
- `source`
- `event_code`
- `occurred_at`
- `network_interface_key`
Use if `order[attributes]` is provided and provide either `asc` or `desc` direction.
Use `page[offset]` to specify which page, as a number, of the results you would like to return in the payload.  By default the first page is returned.
Use `page[limit]` to specify how many results to return on each page.  The default limit is 25.

Filter `access_point_connections` based on `ts_start`.  This filter allows you to provide a single operator and value(s) to filter `ts_start` and `access_point_connections` that fall within the parameters.  

For the `<=>`(between) operator use the `filter[ts_start][value1]` and `filter[ts_start][value2]` providing an epoch timestamp for each.  

For the `<=,<,>,>=` operators use the `filter[ts_start][value]` providing an epoch timestamp.
Use if `filter[ts_start][operator]` is provided and is one of the following: `<=,<,>,>=`.  An epoch timestamp should be entered.

Use if `filter[ts_start][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.  An epoch timestamp should be entered.
Filter `access_point_connections` based on `wifi_profiles`.  You can filter on a single `wifi_profile` or multiple `wifi_profiles` by providing the `wifi_profiles` ids as a comma separated list.
Use `filter[error_states]` to filter only the `access_point_connections` which have any of the specified error_states. One or more of `association`, `authentication` and `dhcp`.

Order payload results based on provided attributes.  You may provide a single attribute or multiple attributes as a comma separated list.  The attributes will be applied in the order they are provided.  Use in conjunction with `order[direction]`.  You may only order attributes in the same direction.  Available attributes for ordering are:

- `ts_attached`
- `ts_detached`
- `dhcp_acquisition_duration`
- `network_connectivity_validation`
- `state`
- `ts_start`
- `wpa_association_duration`
- `wpa_authentication_duration`
Use if `order[attributes]` is provided and provide either `asc` or `desc` direction.
Use `page[offset]` to specify which page, as a number, of the results you would like to return in the payload.  By default the first page is returned.
Use `page[limit]` to specify how many results to return on each page.  The default limit is 25.

Filter which alerts to use to calculate the aggregates based on `ts`.  This filter allows you to provide a single operator and value(s) to filter `ts` and `alerts` that fall within the parameters.
For the `<=>`(between) operator use the `filter[ts][value1]` and `filter[ts][value2]` providing an epoch timestamp for each.

Define how to group the alert aggregates. There are two possible values:
1. By `severity`: to group alert counts per agent per severity number. Severity `1` is a critical alert, and severity `4` is a warning alert.
2. By `alert_detector_id`: to group alerts counts per agent, per alert detector id. The alert detector id represents the id of the alert profile assigned to this test through the Targets user interface. More information on Alert Configurations can be found [here](https://netbeez.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/articles/201580529-Alerts-Configuration).
If you wish to restrict the agents returning aggregate alert counts, you can select them as an array of `agent_id`s using this parameter.

query.description:
Filter `results` based on `ts` (timestamp).  This filter allows you to provide a single operator and value(s) to filter `ts` and `results` that fall within the parameters.  

For the `<=>`(between) operator use the `filter[ts][value1]` and `filter[ts][value2]` providing a unix timestamp for each (in milliseconds).  

For the `<=,<,>,>=` operators use the `filter[ts][value]` providing a unix timestamp.
Use if `filter[ts][operator]` is provided and is one of the following: `<=,<,>,>=`
Use if `filter[ts][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.
Use if `filter[ts][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.

Filter `results` based on `severity` (error: `1`, warning: `4`, success: `6`).  This filter allows you to provide a single operator and value(s) to filter `severity` and `results` that fall within the parameters.  

For the `<=>`(between) operator use the `filter[severity][value1]` and `filter[severity][value2]` providing the desired severity values between 1 and 6.  

For the `<=,<,>,>=` operators use the `filter[severity][value]` providing a value between 1 and 6.
Use if `filter[severity][operator]` is provided and is one of the following: `<=,<,>,>=`
Use if `filter[severity][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.
Use if `filter[severity][operator]` is provided and is `<=>`.
Filter `results` based on `ssid`.  You can filter on a single `ssid` or multiple `ssids` by providing the `ssids` ids as a comma separated list.

Filter `results` based on the `category` of the source agent. `category` can be one of the following values:
- `network_agent`
- `remote_worker_agent`

Filter `results` based on the `agent_classes` of the source agent.  `agent_classes` include following categories: 
- `container`
- `faste`
- `wireless`
-  `cumulus`
-  `external`
-  `gige`
-  `software`
-  `virtual`
-  `mac`
- `windows`
- `igel`
You can filter on a single `agent_class` or multiple `agent_classes` by providing the `agent classes` as a comma separated list.
Filter `results` based on `agents`.  You can filter on a single `agent` or multiple `agents` by providing the `agent` ids as a comma separated list.
Filter `results` based on `last_result` for each `agent` specified using `filter[agents]` or for all `agents` associated to the `scheduled_test` if`filter[agents]` is not provided.

Filter `results` based on whether they have an alert attached to them or not. Set the parameter to `true` to get the results with an alert attached to them, and `false` to get the ones without any alerts on them.

Order payload results based on provided attributes.  You may provide a single attribute or multiple attributes as a comma separated list.  The attributes will be applied in the order they are provided.  Use in conjunction with `order[direction]`.  You may only order attributes in the same direction.  Available attributes for ordering are:
- `ts`
- `severity`
Use if `order[attributes]` is provided and provide either `asc` or `desc` direction.
Use `page[offset]` to specify which page, as a number, of the results you would like to return in the payload.  By default the first page is returned.
Use `page[limit]` to specify how many results to return on each page.  The default limit is 25.

item.name: Reference
Access Point
item.description:
An `access_point` represents WiFi access points that a wireless `agent` connects to. `access_point` does not have any user defined attributes and cannot be modified through the API. ### Attributes | Attribute | Data Type | Description | **User Defined?** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `bssid` | string | Specifies the `bssid` of the connected `access_point`. | **No** | | `ssid` | string | Specifies the `ssid` of the connected `access_point`. | **Yes**
`ssid` must be no longer than 32 characters. | | `protocol` | string | Specifies the `protocol` in use for the `access_point`. | **No** | | `frequency` | number | Specifies the `frequency` in use for the `access_point`. | **No** | | `channel` | number | Specifies the `channel` in use for the connected `access_point`. | **No** | | `mode` | string | Specifies the `mode` for the connected `access_point`. | **No** | | `encryption` | string | Specifies the `encryption` for the connected `access_point`. | **No** | | `bit_rates` | string | Specifies the supported `bit_rates` for the connected `access_point`. | **No** | | `last_seen_ts` | number | Specifies the epoch timestamp of when the connected `access_point` was last seen. | **No** | | `information_entities` | string | Specifies `information_entities` for the connected `access_point`. | **No** | | `security_type` | string | Specifies the `security_type` for the connected `access_point`. | **No** |

item.name: Access Point Connection
item.description:
An `access_point_connection` represents the connection of a wireless `agent` to a `wifi_profile` and the timing of each phase of the connection. ### Attributes | Attribute | Data Type | Description | User Defined? | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `dhcp_acqusition_duration` | number | How long, in milliseconds, it took for an `agent` to acquire a DHCP lease from the associated `wifi_profile`. | **No** | | `error_message` | string | If an error occurs during the `access_point_connection` attempt and will specify the error message that was captured. | **No** | | `error_state` | string | If an error occurs during the `access_point_connection` attempt and will specify which state the failure occurred on. | **No** | | `network_connectivity_verification` | boolean | Was the agent able to connect to the internet? The verification test is defined on the associated `wifi_profile`, if `network_verification_enabled` is not true on the `wifi_profile` this attribute will be `null`. | **No** | | `state` | string | The stage of the `access_point_connection`. `state` will be one of the following values

\- `start_attempt`
\- `association`
\- `authentication`
\- `dhcp`
\- `network_connectivity`
\- `success`
\- `success_disconnected`
\- `connection_lost`
\- `failed` | **No** | | `ts_attached` | number | When the `agent` connected to the associated `wifi_profile`. This is an epoch timestamp. | **No** | | `ts_detached` | number | When the `agent` disconnected to the associated `wifi_profile`. This is an epoch timestamp. | **No** | | `ts_start` | number | When the `agent` started the `access_point_connection` attempt. This is an epoch timestamp. | **No** | | `wpa_assoication_duration` | number | How long, in milliseconds, it took for an `agent` to connect to the defined `ssid` of the associated `wifi_profile`. | **No** | | `wpa_authentication_duration` | number | How long, in milliseconds, it took for an `agent` to authenticate to the defined `ssid` of the associated `wifi_profile`. This only applies if the `encryption_method` of the associated `wifi_profile` is not `open`. | **No** | ### Relationships | Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** | | --- | --- | --- | | `access_point` | One | **No** | | `network_interface` | One | **No** | | `wifi_profile` | One | **No** |

item.name: Agent
item.description:
An `agent` represents a hardware or software agent that can run various network tests and return the test results. Refer to the `User Defined?` column to determine which attributes can be used when utilizing `POST` or `PUT` endpoints. #### Regarding Bulk Updating When using the [bulk updating API](#request-4425180-b275eb1b-8a41-4f09-ba45-bc9f88a887a9) you must also supply the `id` attribute. The `id` must be the `id` of an existing `agent` and this `id` is not used to update the `id` of an `agent` but to look up and identify an `agent` that the change is to be applied to. ### Attributes | **Attribute** | **Data Type** | **Description** | **User Defined?** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `name` | string | User-defined attribute to help identify an `agent`. | **Yes**
Optional, must be no longer than 255 characters. | | `description` | string | User-defined attribute that allows you to add the desired context to your `agent` | **Yes
**Optional, must be no longer than 255 characters. | | `reached_target_test_limit` | boolean | Specifies if the `agent` has reached its limit for `target` tests. | **No** | | `reached_scheduled_test_limit` | boolean | Specifies if the `agent` has reached its limit for `scheduled_tests`. | **No** | | `nb_target_ids` | array | Specifies the `nb_target` ids currently associated. | **No** | | `nb_test_ids` | array | Specifies the `nb_test` ids currently monitoring. | **No** | | `uuid` | string | Generated, or in some cases user-defined, identifier for an `agent`. | **No
**This attribute can not be changed through the API but can be changed in some cases via `agent` configuration. | | `agent_type_name` | string | Specifies the name of the `agent_type` for the `agent`. | **No** | | `os_version` | string | Specifies the operating system version of the `agent` if it can be determined. | **No** | | `kernel_version` | string | Specifies the kernel version of the `agent` if it can be determined. | **No** | | `agent_class` | string | The class of an `agent`. `agent_class` will be one of the following values:


\- `cumulus`
\- `virtual`
\- `gige`
\- `faste`
\- `external`
\- `software`
\- `windows`
\- `mac`
\- `igel` | **No** | | `active` | boolean | Reports if the agent is currently active. | **No** | | `description` | string | User-defined attribute that gives the desired context to the `agent`. | **No** | | `category` | string | The category of an `agent`. `category` will be one of the following values:

\- `network_agent`
\- `remote_worker_agent` | **No** | | `software_version` | string | The reported `software_version` an `agent` is currently running. | **No** | | `open_incident_id` | number | The id of the `incident` that is currently ongoing. | **No** | | `test_aggregate_counts_by_type` | object | Reports the alert counts per `nb_test` type. | **No** | ### Relationships | Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** | | --- | --- | --- | | `agent_groups` | Many | **Yes** | | `network_interfaces` | Many | **No** | | `open_incident` | One | **Yes** | | `scheduled_nb_test_templates` | Many | **Yes** |

item.name: Agent Performance Metric
item.description:
An `agent_performance_metric` represents the status of an `agents` resources at a particular point in time.

### Attributes

| Attribute | Data Type | Description | User Defined? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `ts` | number | Timestamp of when the `agent_performance_metric` is taken. This is an epoch timestamp. | **No** |
| `cpu_utilization` | number | An `agents` cpu utilization represented as a percentage as reported by the operating system. | **No** |
| `memory_utilization` | number | The agent's memory utilization at the time recorded represented as a percentage of the total. | **No** |
| `disk_utilization` | number | The agent's disk space utilization at the time recorded represented as a percentage of the total. | **No** |

### Relationships

| Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `agent` | One | **No** |

item.name: Agent Group
item.description:
An `agent_group` represents groups of `agents`. An `agent_group` also can ensure associated `agents` all run the same `targets`. ### Attributes | Attribute | Data Type | Description | **User Defined?** | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `name` | string | User-defined attribute to help identify an `agent_group`. | **Yes**
Required, must be no longer than 255 characters. | | `auto_assign` | boolean | `auto_assign` specifies that new `agents` connecting NetBeez for the first time will automatically be added to the `agent_group`. There can only be one `agent_group` with `auto_assign` equal to `true` at a time. | **Yes**
`auto_assign` must be either `true` or `false.` | | `agent_count` | number | Number of `agents` currently assigned to the `agent_group`. | **No** | | `targets_count` | number | Number of `nb_targets` currently assigned to the `agent_group`. | **No** | ### Relationships | Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** | | --- | --- | --- | | `agents` | Many | **Yes** | | `nb_targets` | Many | **Yes** |

item.name: Agent Log
item.description:
An `agent_log` represents various log messages that may be received from an `agent`.

### Attributes

| Attribute | Data Type | Description | User Defined? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `event_code` | string | The identifying code of a process or event from the `source` if provided. | **No** |
| `message` | string | This contains the message presented in the log from the log `source`. | **No** |
| `network_interface_key` | string | Represents the network interface the log `source` is regarding. | **No** |
| `occurred_at` | number | The timestamp of when the log occurred. This is an epoch timestamp. | **No** |
| `severity` | string | The log syslog level reported by the `source`. | **No** |
| `source` | string | `source` of where the log event is from. | **No** |

### Relationships

| Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `agent` | One | **No** |
| `network_interface` | One | **No** |

item.name: Alert
item.description:
An `alert` represents an issue encountered by an `agent` while running assigned `tests` based on configured `alert_detectors`.

### Attributes

| Attribute | Data Type | Description | User Defined? |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `alert_ts` | number | Specifies the unix epoch timestamp of when the alert was triggered. | **No** |
| `closed_ts` | number | Specifies the unix epoch timestamp of when the alert was closed if the `alert` is a closing `alert`. | **No** |
| `message` | string | Specifies the `message` that pertains to the alert. | **No** |
| `severity` | number | Specifies the syslog level corresponding to the `alert`. | **No** |
| `severity_name` | number | Specifies the corresponding syslog level name associated to the `severity`. | **No** |
| `status` | string | Specifies if the `alert` is an `open` `alert` or `closed` `alert`. | **No** |
| `created_at` | string | Specifies when the `alert` was created. | **No** |
| `updated_at` | string | Specifies when the `alert` was last updated. | **No** |

### Relationships

| Relationship | One or Many | Optional? |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `opening_alert` | One | **Yes** |
| `alert_detector_instance` | One | **No** |
| `alert_detector` | One | **No** |
| `nb_test` | One | **Yes** |
| `nb_test_template` | One | **Yes** |
| `nb_target` | One | **Yes** |
| `agent` | One | **No** |

item.name: Alert Detector
item.description:
An `alert_detector` represents the conditions in which a `test` run by an `agent` should trigger an `alert`. ### Attributes | Attribute | Data Type | Description | User Defined? | | --- | --- | --- | --- | | `alert_conditions` | string | Specifies the `alert_conditions` in which `alerts` will be created. | **No** | | `alert_detector_type` | string | Specifies the type of `alert_detector` and will be one of the following values:
\- `AgentUpDown`
\- `Baseline`
\-`BaselineWatermark`
\- `UpDown`
\- `Watermark` | **No** | | `alerts_severity` | number | Specifies the `alerts_severity` that generated `alerts` should be given. Follows syslog levels. | **No** | | `attach_by_default` | boolean | Specifies if the `alert_detector` should be attached to a `target` by default when a `target` is created. | **No** | | `created_at` | string | Specifies when the `alert_detector` was created. | **No** | | `function_arguments` | string | Specifies the arguments used for the `alert_detector`. | **No** | | `message` | string | Specifies the `message` that will be presented to users when an `alert` is created. | **No** | | `name` | string | Specifies the User-defined `name` of the `alert_detector`. | **No** | | `reverse_alert_condition` | string | Specifies the conditions in which an `alert` should be closed that was created by the `alert_detector` | **No** | | `reverse_message` | string | Specifies the `reverse_message` that will be presented to users when an `alert` is cleared. | **No** | | `stats_function` | string | Specifies the `stats_function` used for the `alert_detector` , will be one of the following:
\- `count`
\- `PercentageOfCondition`
\- `TestPerformance`
\- `WirelessConnectivityChanges` | **No** | | `stream_source` | string | Specifies the `stream_source` of data where the `alert_dectector` is used, will be one of the following:
\- `results`
\- `statistics` | **No** | | `type_of_alerting_entity` | string | Specifies the `type_of_alerting_entity` the `alert_detector` is for, will be one of the following:
\- `Agent`
\- `NbTest` | **No** | | `updated_at` | string | Specifies when the `alert_detector` was last updated. | **No** | | `window_type` | number | Specifies the `window_type` used by the `alert_detector`, will be one of the following:

\- `monotonic`

\- `sliding` | **No** | | `window_size` | number | Specifies the `window_size` used for the `alert_detector`. | **No** | ### Relationships | Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** | | --- | --- | --- | | `nb_test_type` | One | **Yes** |

item.name: DNS Result
item.description:
An `dns_result` represents the recorded value of a `dns_test` that was run by an `agent`.

### Attributes

| **Attribute** | **Data Type** | **Description** | **User Defined?** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| value | number | The `value` of the test result. | **No** |
| network_interface_type | string | The `network_interface_type` of the test `result`. | **No** |
| error_code | number | If an error occurred during the test then the `error_code` will be given. | **No** |
| ts | number | An epoch timestamp of when the `result` occurred. | **No** |

### Relationships

| Relationship | **One or Many** | **Optional?** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `agent` | One | **No** |
| `nb_test_template` | One | **No** |
| `wifi_profile` | One | **Yes** |

item.name: DNS Test

A `dns_test` represents the configuration that is used when an `agent` tests DNS.

### Attributes

| Attribute | Data Type | Description | **User Defined?** |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| `dns_server` | string | Specified DNS server address. | **Yes** |
| `dns_type` | number | Indicates if the DNS test will be done via UDP (2) or TCP (3). | **Yes** |

### Relationship

| Relationship | **One or Many** | Optional? |
| --- | --- | --- |
